newsitem.title: USA: US transatlantic crudes dry up on closed arbitrage.
newsitem.headline: US transatlantic crudes dry up on closed arbitrage.

text.p: North Sea and West African crudes on the U.S. Gulf Coast dried up on Monday, reflecting the closed transatlantic arbitrage, traders said.
The spread between benchmarks West Texas Intermediate/Cushing and North Sea Brent for March was around $1.30-35 Monday afternoon, after touching as low as $1.05-15 around midday.
The arbitrage was still considered open by a few refiners last week, but dwindling U.S. demand has finally shut the window.
"The arb is closed because the United States doesn't need the crude," said one refiner, citing a prevalence of turnarounds on the Gulf Coast.
U.S. refiners have been plagued by thin margins in recent months, further dampening crude demand, traders said.
Meanwhile, Latin America has unleashed a flood of short-haul barrels onto the Gulf Coast.
"The Venezuelans had the mother of all fire sales last week," said one U.S. refiner, citing a pre-Lenten barrage of aggressively priced light and heavy Venezuelan grades.
Elsewhere, Colombia's state-owned Ecopetrol sold two cargoes of sweet Cusiana crude for loading March 8-13 and March 17-21 to a U.S. refiner, traders said.
The former was sold at April WTI/Cushing minus 34 cents a barrel, while the latter fetched a discount of 28 cents a barrel, they said.
